questiontext.text:
Exercise


Equivalent resistance in an electrical circuit


Current distributes itself in the wires of an electrical circuit so as to minimise the total power consumption i.e. the rate at which heat is produced. The power \((p)\) dissipated in an electrical circuit is given by the product of voltage \((v)\) and current \((i)\) flowing in the circuit, i.e. \(p = vi.\) The voltage across a resistor is the product of current and resistance \((r).\) This means that the power dissipated in a resistor is given by \(p = i^2r.\)


Suppose that an electrical circuit contains three resistors \(r_1, r_2, r_3\) and \(i_1\) represents the current flowing through both \(r_1\) and \(r_2\), and that \((i - i_1)\) represents the current flowing through \(r_3\) (see diagram):

  1. Write down an expression for the power dissipated in the circuit: \(p=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] (for subscripts write e.g. x1 for \(x_1\))
    [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. Show that the power dissipated is a minimum when \(\ \ i_1=\dfrac{r_3}{r_1+r_2+r_3}\ i\).

    \(\quad\)Differentiating with respect to [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]], we get:

    \(\qquad p' =\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] and

    \(\qquad p'' =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

    \(\quad\) Hence, for \(i_1=\dfrac{r_3}{r_1+r_2+r_3}\ i\) the power dissipated is a minimum since ...

    \(\quad\)(select one to complete the sentence)

    [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]
    [[feedback:prt2]]
  3. If \(R\) is the equivalent resistance of the circuit, i.e. of \(r_1,\ r_2\) and \(r_3\), for minimum power dissipation and the corresponding voltage \(V\) across the circuit is given by \(V = iR = i_1(r_1 + r_2)\), find an expression for \(R\).

    \(\quad R=\) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]
    [[feedback:prt3]]

Note: In this problem \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) could be replaced by a single resistor. However, treating them as separate allows the possibility of considering more general situations (variable resistors or temperature dependent resistors).

generalfeedback.text:
1. The power dissipated in the circuit may be written as \[p={@ta1@}.\]

  2. Differentiating with respect to \(i_1\) we obtain \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}i_1}={@ta3@}.\]This is zero when \[{@ev(minp_loc,c=i)@}.\]To check if this represents a minimum we differentiate a second time to find \[\frac{\mathrm{d}^2p}{\mathrm{d}i_1^2}={@ta4@}\]which is positive for any value of \(i_1\). So the previous result represents a minimum.

  3. Finally, to find \(R\), substitute for \(i_1\) in \(iR=i_1(r_1+r_2)\) to obtain \[{@ev(ev(minp_v,minp_loc),c=i)@}\] which means \[R = {@ta6@}.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
